step.title: Setup Steps
step.text: This set of steps will do some preliminary "safety" checks to ensure the local environment is ok and setup some important information.

step.title: Old Code
step.text: This checks for old tarballs (and particularly unpacked distributions) which might confuse the later processing. If this step finds outstanding files you need to remove them before continuing!

step.title: Setup Check
step.text: This should show the last version number published in this branch by looking at the time line in the README file:

step.title: Pick a Version Number
step.text: Please enter the version number to publish. Net-SNMP convention dictates that this be a version number like 5.4 or 5.4.1. Pre-releases that occur before a branch freezes should be appended with ".preN" like 5.4.1.pre2. Release-candidates should be labeled ".rcN" like 5.4.1.rc1.

step.title: Enter the last version number
step.text: Please enter the last version number that the changelog should be generated from. This should be easy for a new release on a branch, but may be more tricky for a main release.

step.title: Defining a second internal version string
Release Parameter Information
update
step.text: We need to make sure your code is up to date and matches the latest sources in this branch.

step.title: Check for changes
step.text: This steps looks for outstanding files that have been modified. There should be no outstanding modifications! If this step finds outstanding modified files you need to check them in or revert them before continuing!

step.title: Source Code Setup
step.text: This set of steps will modify various places within the source code tree to bring it up to date with the new version number about to be published.

step.title: Libtool / Library versioning setup
step.text: These steps will modify the various files in the source tree that contain the version number, show you the changes that will be made and then check in the resulting changes if you approve of them.

step.title: version:libtoolmanualedit
step.text:
You may need to edit Makefile.top to update the library version numbering - see the comments there about LIBCURRENT, LIBAGE and LIBREVISION for details. This is usually only needed for the first pre-release of a given version.
This script will commit the file for you after you're done.

step.title: version:commit
step.text: We'll now commit the Makefile.top file if you've modified it.

step.title: Change The Version Number
step.text: These steps will modify the various files in the source tree that contain the version number, show you the changes that will be made and then check in the resulting changes if you approve of them.

step.title: Modify the source files
step.text: We will now modify files through the code to replace the version number with the newer one.

step.title: Running autoconf to rebuild configure
step.text: We modified configure.in, so we now need to run autoconf to rebuild configure.

step.title: Running svn diff to check changes
step.text: Check the following changes for proper version number differences before we commit the chances.

step.title: Running git commit to commit the changes
step.text: Check the changes in the above diff and then we'll commit the results here if they look ok.
Note in 'dist/release' that this branch is in release candidate mode
Ensure that 'dist/release' doesn't reference this branch

commands.command: git commit -m "{BRANCHPATH} out of Release Candidate" dist/release

step.title: docs:make
step.text: This step will create manual pages from doxygen instrumented code files.

commands.command: if [ -f Makefile ] then make docs make mancp fi

step.title: docs:update
step.text:
This will run git status to figure out what files have changed since the previous man page generation steps were done. After this step, we'll commit all the modified files.
You may find additional files (marked with a ?) that should be added to the svn repository and you'll need to do this by hand before going on to the next step.
Note: based on a recent net-snmp-admin discussion, we're no longer going to be adding the bazillions of man pages that doxygen generates by default. Only important ones should be added.

step.title: docs:manualaddnewman
step.text:
Update man/Makefile.in with details of any new man pages, and run 'git add' on them.
I'll commit these changes for you after you're done.

step.title: Testing Steps
step.text: These steps will help you test the source code to ensure it passes some simple "it works" tests.

step.title: build:distclean
step.text: First we need to clean the existing build tree and start from scratch.

step.title: build:configure
step.text: We need to run configure to set up the build tree.

commands.command: ./configure --cache=config.cache --with-defaults --with-mib-modules='host examples examples/example testhandler tlstm-mib tsm-mib smux Rmon disman/event-mib' --with-transports="IPX TLSTCP DTLSUDP" --with-security-modules="tsm" --enable-ipv6 --enable-embedded-perl --enable-shared

step.title: build:make
step.text: Then we need to build the code

step.title: testing: default tests
step.text: Now we run "make test" which should produce a perfect set up test results. If not, this needs to be fixed or at least understood and accepted as is for some other reason.

step.title: testing: unit-tests
step.text: Now we run the unit-tests which should also produce a perfect set up test results. If not, this needs to be fixed or at least understood and accepted as is for some other reason.

step.title: testing: transports
step.text: Now we run the transport tests which should also produce a perfect set up test results, if your machine supports all the transports. If not, this needs to be fixed or at least understood and accepted as is for some other reason (like you can't do IPv6 on your system).

step.title: code:checkcomments
step.text: This command looks for source code oddities and policy violations.

step.title: Release File Steps
step.text: Certain files in the distribution are built on a per-release basis. These steps will help set up these files.

step.title: code:makedepend
step.text:
This step creates Makefile dependencies using the "distdepend" rule in the top level Makefile.
Note that if you have any additional MIB module code files in the source tree, these will be included in the Makefile dependency list. You may wish to remove these and re-run "make distdepend" before committing the changes.

step.title: code:commitdepend
step.text: This step commits the dependency changes done in the previous step.

step.title: Creating a changelog update
step.text: We need to extract the portions of the change logs committed to the repository.

step.title: changelog:manualedit
step.text:
You need to manually insert the *relevent* portions of 'ChangeLog.add' into the ChangeLog file.
I also suggest truncating ChangeLog.add to only contain the *relevent* portions for this release, as this will make CHANGES.new2 and NEWS.new2 more accurate later on.
I'll commit these changes for you after you finish cutting out the proper changes.

step.title: docs:README
step.text: You need to manually insert the relevent portions of 'CHANGES.new' and 'NEWS.new' into the CHANGES and NEWS file. (There are alternative versions in 'CHANGES.new2' and 'NEWS.new2') You may wish to update the README file as well. I'll commit these changes for you afterwards

commands.command: git commit -m "version update for {VERSION}" README NEWS CHANGES

step.title: release:update
step.text: One more git pull and status to make sure nothing odd exists in your source tree. Please check the results!

step.title: Make the Release
step.text: This is it! After this point it's much harder to turn back. If everything is ok until this point and you're ready to actually tag the release in git and make release files, these steps will do that for you.

step.title: release:tag
step.text:
This will actually svn copy the current checked out branch to the new tag name. Specifically:
git tag -u A77C5329 -s {VERSIONTAGNAME} -m "Tagging of version {VERSION} as {VERSIONTAGNAME}"

commands.command: git tag -u A77C5329 -s {VERSIONTAGNAME} -m "Tagging of version {VERSION} as {VERSIONTAGNAME}"

step.name: release:nextbranch
step.title: Don't propagate code modifications
step.text: Mark these code modifications as specific to this particular branch

step.name: release:push
step.title: Push the code modifications
step.text: Push the code modifications to the upstream branch

step.title: Release File Test
step.text: We'll also re-build the source and retest a few things to ensure the packaged file can actually be built.

commands.command: cd net-snmp-{VERSION} && ./configure --cache=config.cache --with-defaults --with-mib-modules='host examples examples/example testhandler smux Rmon disman/event-mib' --with-transports=IPX --enable-ipv6 --enable-embedded-perl --enable-shared

step.title: Release the results
step.text: Now we'll publish the results to the SF server

step.title: rsync the new files
step.text: This will copy the results to the SF uploads directory in your account on frs.sourceforge.net. The following command is just as an example - this script does *not* upload the files automatically. You must do something like:

commands.command: echo rsync -v net-snmp-{VERSION}.tar.gz net-snmp-{VERSION}.tar.gz.asc net-snmp-{VERSION}.zip net-snmp-{VERSION}.zip.asc hardaker,net-snmp@frs.sourceforge.net:/home/frs/project/n/ne/net-snmp/net-snmp/{VERSIONTARGET}-pre-releases/

step.title: rsync the new files
step.text: This will copy the results to the SF uploads directory in your account on frs.sourceforge.net. The following command is just as an example - this script does *not* upload the files automatically. You must do something like:

commands.command: echo rsync -v net-snmp-{VERSION}.tar.gz net-snmp-{VERSION}.tar.gz.asc net-snmp-{VERSION}.zip net-snmp-{VERSION}.zip.asc hardaker,net-snmp@frs.sourceforge.net:/home/frs/project/n/ne/net-snmp/net-snmp/{VERSIONTARGET}/

step.title: Update the SF release web page
step.text: Update the project download web page (http://www.net-snmp.org/download.html) to mention this new release

step.title: Update the SF Official Patch tracker
step.text: If this the final version of this release, then: Any official patches for the previous release should be re-prioritised to level 5. Any official patches for the earlier releases should be re-prioritised to level 1 and closed.
Binaries: build rpms, .tar.gzs, etc.

step.name: cleanup:nsrollup
step.title: Run nsrollup
step.text:
You need to run nsrollup now to sync all the changes we've made into any upstream branches. This will likely cause merge conflicts because of the version number clashes and will need to be resolved.
Run (in bash):
. local/gittools/shell-functions nsrollup nssync
XXX: For conflicts, we can probably pick -s ours but needs to be checked and documented.

step.title: Add note to the news system
step.text:
Add a note to the source forge news system:
http://sourceforge.net/news/submit.php?group_id=12694

Send an announcement message to one of the following mailing lists based on its type:
pre: net-snmp-coders@lists.sourceforge.net
rc: net-snmp-users@lists.sourceforge.net
final: net-snmp-announce@lists.sourceforge.net (one week after the source tarball is made available)
Update the topic on the #Net-SNMP channel if this is a trunk based release.

Update the freshmeat listing (Wes needs to do this):
http://freshmeat.net/projects/net-snmp/
Advertise: NEWS upload to sf, publish on -announce, freshmeat, and the GNU FSF directory (http://directory.fsf.org/project/net-snmp/)... (send mail to bug-directory@gnu.org)
